items.standfirst: Court rules Paetongtarn Shinawatra breached ethics in call where she called Hun Sen "uncle" shortly before border conflict.
items.content: Court rules Paetongtarn Shinawatra breached ethics in call where she called Hun Sen "uncle" shortly before border conflict.

items.content: Thailand's Constitutional Court on Friday dismissed Paetongtarn Shinawatra from her position as prime minister, ruling that as the country's leader she violated constitutional rules on ethics.(Image credit: Sakchai Lalit)

items.content: Thailand's Constitutional Court has removed the country's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra from office.

items.title: How a leaked phone call derailed the Thai PM's career - and the Shinawatra dynasty
items.standfirst: Thailand's Constitutional Court strikes again, removing yet another prime minister from office.
items.content: Thailand's Constitutional Court strikes again, removing yet another prime minister from office.

items.title: Thai court dismisses prime minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra
items.standfirst: Daughter of former PM Thaksin accused of failing to protect country’s interests over leaked phone call with Cambodia’s leaderThailand’s constitutional court has dismissed Paetongtarn Shinawatra from her position as prime minister, ruling that as the country’s leader she violated constitutional rules on ethics in a phone call with Cambodia’s senate president, Hun Sen.The ruling, which ushers in a fresh period of instability in the country, means she immediately loses her job, which she had held for about a year. The 39-year-old had already been suspended from her duties on 1 July after a recording was leaked of her phone conversation with Hun Sen, in which they discussed a simmering border dispute between the neighbouring countries. Continue reading...
items.content: Daughter of former PM Thaksin accused of failing to protect country’s interests over leaked phone call with Cambodia’s leaderThailand’s constitutional court has dismissed Paetongtarn Shinawatra from her position as prime minister, ruling that as the country’s leader she violated constitutional rules on ethics in a phone call with Cambodia’s senate president, Hun Sen.The ruling, which ushers in a fresh period of instability in the country, means she immediately loses her job, which she had held for about a year. The 39-year-old had already been suspended from her duties on 1 July after a recording was leaked of her phone conversation with Hun Sen, in which they discussed a simmering border dispute between the neighbouring countries. Continue reading...

items.title: Thai Court Dismisses Premier Paetongtarn for Ethics Violation
Thai court removes PM Paetongtarn Shinawatra from office
Thai court sacks PM Paetongtarn Shinawatra for ‘ethics violations’ over handling of border clash
items.standfirst: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra was dismissed Friday by the country's Constitutional Court over her handling of a border clash with neighbouring Cambodia. The court said Paetongtarn had violated ethics in what her critics viewed as an overly friendly phone call with Cambodia's former prime minister Hun Sen that was leaked to the press.
items.content: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra was dismissed Friday by the country's Constitutional Court over her handling of a border clash with neighbouring Cambodia. The court said Paetongtarn had violated ethics in what her critics viewed as an overly friendly phone call with Cambodia's former prime minister Hun Sen that was leaked to the press.

items.title: Thai court removes Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra from office

items.content: Court dismisses suspended prime minister for ethical misconduct over her handling of a border row with Cambodia.

items.content: Thailand's prime minister has been sacked after a leaked phone call with a senior Cambodian politician caused outrage.

ai_summary: Thailand's Constitutional Court removed Paetongtarn Shinawatra from her position as prime minister.
The court ruled she violated ethics rules in a phone call with Cambodia's leader.
The phone call involved discussion of a border dispute between the two countries.
The ruling resulted in her immediate loss of the prime minister position.
She had been suspended from duties after a leaked recording of the phone call.

items.title: Fed governor Lisa Cook sues Trump over his ‘illegal attempt’ to fire her
items.standfirst: US president spent months waging campaign against Fed’s leaders, which has raised questions over its independenceThe Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook has filed a lawsuit against Donald Trump over his “unprecedented and illegal attempt” to fire her, calling it an attempt to undermine the central bank’s independence.The lawsuit – filed by Cook in federal court in Washington on Thursday – sets the stage for a legal battle over the US president’s extraordinary push for greater control of the central bank. items.title: Mont Fuji: AI-generated video prepares Japan for its eruption
items.standfirst: Japanese officials have released AI-generated videos simulating a potential violent eruption of the active volcano #MountFuji. While there are currently no signs of activity, experts warn that if an eruption occurs, ash could reach Tokyo within 1–2 hours, with 2–10 cm expected to accumulate.
items.content: Japanese officials have released AI-generated videos simulating a potential violent eruption of the active volcano #MountFuji. While there are currently no signs of activity, experts warn that if an eruption occurs, ash could reach Tokyo within 1–2 hours, with 2–10 cm expected to accumulate.

items.title: An AI simulation of a Mount Fuji eruption is being used to prepare Tokyo for the worst
items.standfirst: Mount Fuji hasn’t erupted since 1707. But for Volcanic Disaster Preparedness Day, Japanese officials have released computer- and AI-generated videos showing a simulation of a potential violent eruption of the active volcano.
items.content: Mount Fuji hasn’t erupted since 1707. But for Volcanic Disaster Preparedness Day, Japanese officials have released computer- and AI-generated videos showing a simulation of a potential violent eruption of the active volcano.

items.title: AI-generated video prepares Tokyo residents for Mount Fuji eruption
items.standfirst: Tokyo officials released an AI-generated video showing a simulation of a potential violent eruption of Mount Fuji, which lies about 60 miles from Tokyo. The active volcano has been dormant for over 300 years, but the AI-generated video is being used to prepare Tokyo’s 37-million residents for potential disasters.
items.content: Tokyo officials released an AI-generated video showing a simulation of a potential violent eruption of Mount Fuji, which lies about 60 miles from Tokyo. The active volcano has been dormant for over 300 years, but the AI-generated video is being used to prepare Tokyo’s 37-million residents for potential disasters.

items.content: Japanese officials have released an AI-generated video showing a simulation of Mount Fuji violently erupting to raise awareness about a potential disaster.

items.standfirst: Tokyo authorities say they released the AI-generated video to raise awareness and help people prepare for disaster - but how likely is Mt Fuji to actually erupt?
items.content: Tokyo authorities say they released the AI-generated video to raise awareness and help people prepare for disaster - but how likely is Mt Fuji to actually erupt?

Mount Fuji has been dormant for over three hundred years.

items.content: France, Germany and the United Kingdom moved Thursday to reimpose United Nations sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program, further isolating Tehran after its atomic sites were repeatedly bombed during a 12-day war with Israel.

items.content: The three powers trigger a process which could restore sanctions in 30 days, calling Iran's nuclear programme a threat to peace and security.

items.title: 33 Colombian soldiers freed after 'kidnapping' in guerrilla-held Amazon
items.standfirst: Dozens of Colombian soldiers reportedly held against their will by villagers in an area of the Amazon known for its extensive drug crops were released Thursday, the country's Ombudsman's office said. Government forces continue to clash with armed groups who rejected a 2016 peace deal between Bogota and the FARC guerrilla organisation.
items.content: Dozens of Colombian soldiers reportedly held against their will by villagers in an area of the Amazon known for its extensive drug crops were released Thursday, the country's Ombudsman's office said.
